rev.comment: /* Beginnings */ Added the fact that their S-1 contained "don't be evil", and some detail
rev.diff:
Line 35: Line 35:
At its peak in early [[2004]], Google handled upwards of 80 percent of all search requests on the world wide web through its Web site and clients like [[Yahoo!]], [[AOL]], and [[CNN]].[http://www.onestat.com/html/aboutus_pressbox21.html] Google's share fell in February [[2004]] when Yahoo! dropped Google's search technology in order to deliver independent results. As further evidence of Google's popularity, the word "Google" has entered North American [[slang]] as a verb meaning, "to perform a web search (using Google's search engine)".
At its peak in early [[2004]], Google handled upwards of 80 percent of all search requests on the world wide web through its Web site and clients like [[Yahoo!]], [[AOL]], and [[CNN]].[http://www.onestat.com/html/aboutus_pressbox21.html] Google's share fell in February [[2004]] when Yahoo! dropped Google's search technology in order to deliver independent results. As further evidence of Google's popularity, the word "Google" has entered North American [[slang]] as a verb meaning, "to perform a web search (using Google's search engine)".
â
Google's declared [[code of conduct]] is "[[Don't Be Evil]]". Their site includes humorous features such as cartoon modifications [http://www.google.com/holidaylogos.html] of their logo for special occasions, the option to display the site in fictional or humorous languages such as [[Klingon]][http://www.google.com/intl/xx-klingon/] and [[Leet]][http://www.google.com/intl/xx-hacker/], and [[April Fool's]] jokes [http://www.google.com/googlegulp/] about the company.
+
Google's declared [[code of conduct]] is "[[Don't Be Evil]]", a phrase which they went so far as to include in their [[prospectus]] (AKA "red herring" or "S-1") for their [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]], noting "We believe strongly that in the long term, we will be better served â as shareholders and in all other ways â by a company that does good things for the world even if we forgo some short term gains." That this statement was in their initial filing is important from a corporate perspective. Were it not, they would be obligated to sacrifice this ideal in order to maintain shareholder value where the two came into conflict.
  +   +
Their site includes humorous features such as cartoon modifications [http://www.google.com/holidaylogos.html] of their logo for special occasions, the option to display the site in fictional or humorous languages such as [[Klingon]][http://www.google.com/intl/xx-klingon/] and [[Leet]][http://www.google.com/intl/xx-hacker/], and [[April Fool's]] jokes [http://www.google.com/googlegulp/] about the company.
It is conjectured that Google's response to Yahoo will be personalized searches, using the personal data that is gathering from [[Orkut]], [[Gmail]], and [[Froogle]] to give results based on the individual. In fact, there is a [http://labs.google.com/personalized Personalized Google Search] Beta in [http://labs.google.com/ Google Labs], the experimental section of Google.com.
It is conjectured that Google's response to Yahoo will be personalized searches, using the personal data that is gathering from [[Orkut]], [[Gmail]], and [[Froogle]] to give results based on the individual. In fact, there is a [http://labs.google.com/personalized Personalized Google Search] Beta in [http://labs.google.com/ Google Labs], the experimental section of Google.com.
